awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2021 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. 

The title of the project for this fellowship to Xiaoyu He is "Extremal Combinatorics". The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Alon Noga

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During 2021-2024, I was supported by an NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (MSPRF) to the amount of $150,000, conducted at Princeton University under the supervision of Professor Noga Alon.  The proposal focused on extremal combinatorics, especially probabilistic methods in extremal graph theory and Ramsey theory. During the course of the fellowship, I produced 15 research papers in the areas surrounding extremal and probabilistic combinatorics, made major inroads on the growth rates of hypergraph Ramsey numbers, and developed significant connections between Ramsey theory and the theory of error-correcting codes in theoretical computer science.

Especially in the area of hypergraph Ramsey theory, I made significant progress on the hard project in my proposal of determining growth rates in the off-diagonal case, determining the growth rates of such Ramsey numbers for a much larger class of 3-uniform hypergraphs than was previously understood.

I am pleased to report the discovery of fascinating connections between my work in Ramsey theory and the problems and results in coding theory. As one key example, with Conlon, Fox, Mubayi, Suk, and Verstraete we gave essentially tight bounds for most set-coloring Ramsey numbers using a coloring construction depending on the existence of error-correcting codes.

I am grateful that the fellowship gave me the opportunity to work with the burgeoning combinatorics group at Princeton and to mentor several stellar undergraduate and graduate students there. Between my work with REU students on coding theory and joint development of the combinatorics reading seminar with graduate students, I believe I have made a lasting impact on the combinatorics research ecosystem there.
